author: timbeiko
content:
I agree that this is a concern, but it's worth noting a couple asymmetries in the decision process:

1. Many of the EOF supporters, client devs, have a full time job that includes engaging with the process. This is not true of the broader community, so when several important stakeholders take time out of their "main thing" to come and signal they have concerns about a feature, we should listen. The past few days weren't the first time someone raised potential issues about EOF, it's happened pretty regularly throughout the process. 

2. A decision to remove something can always be undone, whereas one to include a feature cannot. This isn't the only example of a feature that we've pulled in Ethereum's history because some client teams had issues. EIP-2537 probably got pulled from the most forks due to concerns about the API design and/or library stability. Personally, my bar would have been far higher had a minority tried to push for the inclusion of something vs. its removal. This is, in part, why I also don't think adding a last-minute EIP to replace EOF is a good idea.

also, the EOF that's being shipped is much larger than the EOF i originally started evaluating (around shanghai era). you can't just add or remove features and have it be the same spec -- due to gas and code introspection, EOF just started to grow more and more "features" like TXCREATE, and now EXTCODETYPE and CALL_GAS_SPLIT. so it's a completely different EOF than what i originally started evaluating.

i have actually been dissenting against EOF for awhile now (a year+)? if i made a mistake anywhere it was not formally and loudly dissenting earlier. earlier, i gave my opinion that other things should be prioritized ahead of EOF, but maybe my communication style was overly polite.

author: gcolvin
content:
>  Could someone actually say why some people are willing to die on a hill for EOF?
Because I cannot write a linear-time compiler for EVM to anything else in the current EVM -- it can take quadratic time.  

Because for the same reason much of static analysis and formal verification can take quadratic time -- and those are the customers that ensure security for everyone else.

And because I and others have been trying to fix this for ten years now, with proposals failing as late in the process in as possible.  How many rug pulls must we endure?

author: demiurgos_23
content: it's not about dying on a hill for EOF, it's dying on a hill for a better EVM, the current one is quiet simply a poor man's implementation of a 256bit stack based turing machine, there is a reason programming languages opt for runtime based on structures similar to EOF, it offers analysabilty in reasonable time, verifiable code, we attempted and are attempting to precompile legacy bytecode to MSIL and not knowing which JUMPDEST is actually a jumpdest and which one is a NOP in disguise is impossible code takes non-linear time to analyze and compile, amortization is unpredictable, deadcode elimination is tedious,  and the fact data and code are mixed randomly in current EVM makes it even much much difficult to know which is actually dead code and which is just data being read as bytecode for the analyzers, and the fact that all the bytecode is one single huge function make the emitted code huge and hard for the CLR's jit to handle and optimize further, EOF offered smaller functions, static jumps, no more jumpdests, no more data mixed with code, we can emit structs with defined methods we can essentially build a better EVM implementation, we can analyse purity of code sections, find out const-eval function calls, structure and function sections and static jumpdest along side the stack validation are pretty good additions and almost every other VM under major languages has them for a reason.

author: potuz

The most I read about this the most I worry. I have seen well stated technical arguments on both sides. But for each technical argument against EOF, I have seen a pretty convincing reply from Ipsilon team, Solidity, etc. And then there is a whole different rally about users, how core devs are not relatable to users, how this EIP is not user focused, etc. While there is clearly a need to involve more of the wide user community on ACD, it is not less true that these arguments like "I have been talking to users", "users demand competitiveness of Ethereum", "We are required to be on warmode", etc. are simply non-tangible concepts that are not measurable and are at the same time not debatable since no one  that is data driven can actually disagree (nor agree for that matter). I am very weary that decisions in Ethereum government body would be guided by some ethereal concept that can only be based on hearsay and not in a clearly articulated list of effects that a proposal would have in the UX of the chain. There are two sets of loosely defined concepts that have been used against this EIP: "users should be the focus first" and "complexity is blowing up". Both are highly subjective and I believe that the first concept is being used in an unfair and unbased manner with this EIP, while the second has been discussed at large and the people with the highest knowledge and more worried about the protocol complexity had agreed numerous times (with some exceptions being the minority) that it was worth the effort. 

Again, I am not part of the technical discusion of EOF, but I am incredibly dissapointed to see a side drop an EIP with non-measurable effects and appeals to "users desires" when these are ultimately not really known nor provably known and when every single concrete example was appropriately addressed.

It chooses the strategy of rollup aggregator as a sole strategy, giving up on the strategy of the smart contract platform (again, rightly or wrongly). As <@683653554631868440> keeps pointing out correctly, EVM has been primitively designed, compared to anything that is out there: BPF (used in Solana), WASM, JVM, Risk-V, etc. But there is another problem, which I call "incomprehensive state problem", which is not widely understood, but it is the reason why some form of archive nodes will always be required. Solana, with all its drawbacks, has better VM (because it chose not to invent it), and comprehensible state (because, having chosen not to invent VM, it did not need to invent new programming languages). Fixings these 2  things does require going for EOF. Not fixing them is also OK, but it needs to be understood what future directions are forfeited thereby

author: .vbuterin
content: Which is that large changes have a high fixed cost (to devs, to application devs, to infrastructure, etc)

author: .vbuterin

author: .vbuterin
content: so I don't see EOF vs no EOF as being decisive for "the vision of what L1 is for", purely because EOF's pros and cons are both of the "1.5x" flavor rather than the "10x" flavor
